title: Anaphylaxis (Severe Allergic Reaction)
summary: Life-threatening allergic reaction requiring immediate epinephrine injection and emergency medical care.

steps.title: Recognize Anaphylaxis
steps.description: Look for: difficulty breathing, swelling of face/throat, rapid pulse, skin rash/hives, nausea/vomiting, feeling of doom. Can occur within minutes of exposure to allergen. Act immediately.

steps.title: Give Epinephrine Immediately
steps.description: Use epinephrine auto-injector (EpiPen) if available. Remove safety cap, press firmly into outer thigh through clothing, hold for 10 seconds. Note time given. Call 911 even if symptoms improve.

steps.title: Call 911
steps.description: Call 911 immediately after giving epinephrine. Tell dispatcher it's anaphylaxis. Person needs hospital monitoring even if improving - symptoms can return. Give second dose after 5-15 minutes if no improvement.

steps.title: Position and Monitor
steps.description: Help person lie on back with legs elevated unless breathing is difficult - then let them sit up. Loosen tight clothing. Cover with blanket if cold. If vomiting, turn on side. Begin CPR if needed.

steps.title: Continue Care
steps.description: Stay with person. Keep them calm. Note what triggered reaction for medical team. If prescribed, give antihistamine (Benadryl) after epinephrine, but never as substitute. Save used auto-injector for EMTs.

warnings: Epinephrine is the ONLY first-line treatment - antihistamines alone won't stop anaphylaxis
Don't wait to see if symptoms get worse - give epinephrine immediately
A second reaction can occur hours later (biphasic reaction)
whenToSeekHelp: Call 911 immediately for all anaphylaxis cases
Hospital monitoring required even if symptoms improve
Anyone using epinephrine must go to emergency room
preventionTips: Always carry two epinephrine auto-injectors if prescribed
Wear medical alert bracelet listing allergies
Read food labels carefully and ask about ingredients
